related_questions.question: What is the projected raise for Social Security next year?

related_questions.title: Social Security COLA increase: Group warns of 'problems' - WATE

related_questions.question: Can you get $3,000 a month in Social Security?
related_questions.title: AI Overview
list: Maximum Benefit at Full Retirement Age: In 2025, the maximum Social Security benefit for someone retiring at their full retirement age is $4,018 per month, according to AARP.
Maximum Benefit at Age 70: If you delay retirement until age 70, the maximum benefit increases further, reaching $5,108 per month in 2025, according to SmartAsset.

Earning History: To qualify for the maximum benefit, you need to have earned at or above the maximum taxable amount for Social Security for 35 years. The maximum taxable amount in 2024 was $176,100, according to CBS News.
Cost of Living Adjustments (COLA): Social Security benefits are adjusted annually for inflation through a cost-of-living adjustment (COLA).

Working While Receiving Benefits: Working while receiving benefits can affect your payments, but there are rules about how earnings impact benefits, especially before full retirement age, according to the Social Security Administration (SSA).
Special Earnings Limit Rule: There's a special rule that allows for full Social Security benefits for any month considered retired, regardless of yearly earnings, once you reach full retirement age.

Recalculation of Benefits: If your benefits were reduced due to earnings before full retirement age, the Social Security Administration will recalculate your benefit amount when you reach full retirement age, according to the SSA.

related_questions.question: How much did SS benefits increase from 2022 to 2023?
related_questions.snippet: In 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, and 2024, the Social Security COLAs of 2.8%, 1.6%, 1.3%, 5.9%, 8.7%, and 3.2%, respectively, were large enough that small shares of Medicare Part B enrollees (about 3.5%, 3%, 2%, 1.5%, 0.3%, and 0.5%, respectively) were held harmless and paid lower premiums.

related_questions.question: Will Social Security beneficiaries see a 2.5% Cola in 2025?
related_questions.snippet: Millions of Social Security beneficiaries have now received their first benefit checks for 2025. The new 2.5% cost-of-living adjustment — which adds $50 per month to retirement benefits on average — marks the lowest increase since 2021, when inflation spiked shortly thereafter.
